story:
What our service will bring to the rental market

Our web application will introduce a new modern method of tenant and landlord interaction in a better, faster, safer and paperless way. Our goal as a company is to promote an ethical and fair process for both parties (landlord and tenant). 

 We plan to level the playing field when it comes to renting by ensuring fairness on both sides of the equation with our new process. We will guarantee that both parties are treated fairly, in an ethical way. To do this, we will provide a service to streamline the application and contract process between landlords and tenants, improving upon the current utility provider services model that is offered, guaranteed representation for both parties through our new representation model, as well as some other features that will add to the rental experience. 

 By providing our service, our web application will close the financial gap in this industry as both landlords and tenants will be able to organize their needs; 

  • Extended Contract Service, paperless. 
  • Guaranteed rental payment on time to the landlord by managing a better payment model for the tenant, reducing the effort from both the landlord and tenant.
  • Landlords and tenants will interact with each other in a unique and efficient way, adding ease and peace of mind to the rental experience. 

We have 3 main missions as a company: 

  • Promote fairness to all parties. 
  • Treat each person as the unique individual that they are. 
  • Translate ethics into the rental model and guarantee each party will have fair treatment in the entire experience.


Who are we?

Ali AlQahtani (27), a rising entrepreneur in the rental market. In 2005, I graduated high school in the top 1% in all of Saudi Arabia and passed my ACT in the top 5% internationally. From there, I started my degree in Mechanical Engineering at King Saud University in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia and transferred to NYU to complete it. The true beginning to my career started at American Express. While there, I developed the “You Are My Customer program”: this created the opportunity to pay rent month by month through American Express, as opposed 6 months advance pay in the following countries: Dubai, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Oman, and Bahrain. American Express presented me with the GNS President's Award in 2010 and granted me the opportunity to continue schooling in the United States. I will be graduating from Gannon University the 2016-2017 school year with two more degrees in Accounting, Risk Management Insurance and minoring in Finance.

Michael Hanna (31), a rising entrepreneur with a strong technical background. In 2002 I graduated from high school through an advanced 2-year high school program, Computer Information Systems.  In that program the class worked on a capstone project for a competition during our senior year, which I lead development of the software system we created.  The concept was a virtual classroom for the elementary level.  That project won the regional competition and was showcased at the state level.  Along with the work I did personally on that project, I was able to secure an IT Internship with a local fortune 500 company.  I worked full-time as an intern while attending college and completed a complete redesign of an internal website servicing around 200 users, among other projects.  After completing my Associates Degree of Science in Internet Information Systems, I was hired on full-time and have been working there continuously for the last 13 years, presently a Senior Software Systems Engineer.  In addition to that job I have also done freelance work on the side, designing, developing, and launching 5 websites over the last 4 years.

Personal Successes

With one degree in Mechanical Engineering already acquired, two degrees in Accounting and Risk Management Insurance with a minor in Finance that are soon to be obtained, Ali has secured himself academically.  With 13 years in the web space and Information Technology field, Michael has proven his skills time and time again.

The You Are Our Customer program and GNS President's Award were not Ali's only triumphs. In 2010 and 2011, Ali created a Youth Art & Entertainment program in two different malls in Saudi Arabia. One month out of every summer, Ali offered this program in two booths in two separate malls. The overall profit from each booth totaled $150,000, which allowed him to start the You Are Our Customer program while working with American Express. 


What We Want to Achieve

We’ve both dreamt of creating a means by which we can add significant value and impact to the current world, and believe we have found a way to do so. By effecting significant change in the renting market and redefining the process it operates upon, we will create a fair trade tool for landlords and tenants. A more secure environment by which this process can flourish. The initial patents for this project have been granted.


Our Plans With This Campaign Funding

Our goal is to raise $40,000 USD to allow us to hit the ground running. There are various costs to the startup including:

  • 4 different encryption services
  • Cyber and Financial Insurance
  • Legal Construction Fees
  • Certified Public Account Fees
  • URL Domain Purchasing
  • Current and Future Patent Costs

All of these investments will allow us to provide secure, comprehensive, and fair practices to those who are interested in using our services.

What we can do for you:

As a new service in a new age, there are many unique pros in using this tool. Firstly, you will be able to comprehensively personalize your information so that we may better serve you as a landlord/tenant. Secondly, there is guaranteed representation for both parties involved when using this service. 

We will always ensure fair deposit distribution and returns for the parties involved. 

Thirdly, this service will be user friendly, simple, and available on mobile phones via our app. Lastly, our service will take many responsibilities and pain points off the landlord and the tenant. For example, when signing with us, the task of switching the name under which the utility bill is issued will be left to our services to handle as opposed to the landlord and the tenant.


What if the goal amount isn't reached?

This project is already in development and has an approved patent. If our goal of $40,000 USD isn't reached, any donations will strictly go to building the App and standing up the core service.

Why will this be valuable?

When our service is fully operational, the impact created will be monumental. 

The goal is to create a new tool for a new age, revolutionizing and reinventing the process on which the rental market functions:

  • Creating standards of conduct for landlords and tenants
  • Simplifying and providing security for both parties in the financial aspects of renting
  • Providing equal representation for all parties involved
  • Educating those who are new to renting 
  • Ensuring that there is no gray area in the guidelines set out by our services
  • Simplifying the tasks required today from landlords and tenants, and in some cases, automating the manual tasks to help reduce or eliminate certain burdens.

Risks & Challenges

As with any business endeavor, there are obstacles to be overcome. In this instance, one of our concerns is guaranteeing that any landlord in question is receiving payment on time and in full, whether it be regarding rent, utilities, damages, etc. 

Another worry is the introduction of this service. It is brand new and will redefine the way rental services are handled. We aspire to get the word out and show the world a new way to handle the rental process. 

While these things do weigh upon us and present a significant hurdle to jump, we are equipped to address these risks and assuage any worries that may be presented. 

While studying for his second and third degrees at Gannon University, Ali also interned at a local law firm. While there, he studied the legal handling of any rental dispute. Furthermore, he educated himself on the laws and procedures regarding the rental system that are currently implemented in Pennsylvania. We feel confident that our team will be able to overcome the financial obstacle presented. 

When it comes to introducing our service to the rest of the rental community, much of the advertising will be done during our testing period. During the first four months of this period, we will work with local landlords. Word of mouth and personally engaging with landlords will be our main advertisement. This will allow us to personally witness and address any changes needed to further perfect our service.

After the testing period, we plan on branching out and holding a grand opening conference with local businesses in northwestern Pennsylvania. From there, we will implement the use of social media and advertisement through business acquired. Eventually, we will expand the advertisement statewide, giving us more opportunity to get the word out that we are the new and improved way of handling the rental process.  From there, we will be able to bring this benefit nationwide in phases.

Another solution to introducing this new product will come from the large network we've created. Being well-traveled and educated, we've amassed a large network of incredible and successful acquaintances and friends. With their help, we trust that the introduction of our company will spread like wildfire. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We recognize that not all people interested in this business venture will be able to donate, but there are other ways you can help us spread the word that there is an improved service available on the market! 

If you know of any landlords, tenants, or housing services that might be interested in our project, please remember to share this opportunity with them via Facebook, the indiegogo share options, phone call, email, or even a quick plug into your next social event!

story:
Blue Sky Longboards, Support A Skateboard Company That Stands For Something Bigger

Blue Sky Longboards needs your help to raise $35,000 to continue building record setting skateboards and doing good for our communities.

Matt Burke founded Blue Sky Longboards in 2011 as a skateboard company with a mission.  That mission is to create the highest quality longboards and give people the tools to support their communities by engaging in charitable fundraising.  The community side of the Blue Sky mission started with the moto of “Pushing Wood and Doin’ Good” which is now the name of the philanthropic initiative at the heart of the company.

Blue Sky’s skateboards are a world class product built with American craftsmanship using American hard maple. Their production partner Chapman Manufacturing, has been featured on CNBC as a great 'Made in America' business, and has helped them develop the "Timeless Lineup."  8 permanent shapes that cover all disciplines of skateboarding.  Blue Sky’s team of 20 riders represent the brand around the world. By riding Blue Sky boards they have won their way to the top of many podiums, and set several world records.

The Pushing Wood & Doin' Good initiative is simple; 10 skaters get ten people each to sponsor them for $1 a mile. Together they skate for 10 miles and raise $1,000 for the charity of the their choice. Not only is this great for the charity but it is fantastic for the kids involved in the push.

Blue Sky Longboards helps foster support for these events by gathering together companies from around the industry to provide awards and incentives to individuals who do the most fundraising.  The Pushing Wood & Doin' Good initiative has already skated countless hours as a community and raised thousands of dollars for youth oriented charities such as STOKED and the A.Skate Foundation.

  


Over the next 5 years Blue Sky Longboards plans to expand the Pushing Wood and Doin’ Good initiative to reach the point where it raises over $100,000 for local charities across the country.  The program will grow every year as it reaches out to more communities from coast to coast, providing the incentive and organization for them to fundraise for their communities.  Through these years of development, Blue Sky will help people skate more than 30,000 miles and raise over $250,000 for local charities.


What Blue Sky Needs & Why

Unfortunately, Matt Burke has lost majority ownership of the company that he has been dreaming about for 4 decades. The current owner is backing out and Matt is working to raising $35,000 to buy back the company, pay for the current inventory and move forward with more Pushing Wood & Doing Good events. Without your help, Blue Sky may be finished.

Your donations will help keep Blue Sky’s doors open and move forward towards the goal of helping skaters raise $100,000 annually for charities, across the country and around the world.

A note from Matt Burke:

"We hope you can make a contribution, but we understand that not everybody can contribute financially. You can still be a critical part of our mission, please share our campaign with any and all of your connections. Our success depends on people like you caring and sharing."


Press Coverage
Thane Magazine
Skate the East
Longboard Paradise Radio


Side Notes

The founder of Blue Sky is also responsible for creating one of the fastest growing skateboard communities on Facebook. The group is called #showmeatrick      (Show Me A Trick) and already has more than 6,000 members and 5,000 user generated videos uploaded by professional and amateur riders from around the world. This group is a positive place for the next generation to learn new tricks and get pointers from more experienced skaters. 

“The engagement is fantastic! Which I think can be attributed to having a platform with such a wide audience and inherently engaging content. Very cool to see.”

- Kyle Chin, Loaded Skateboards

“The "Show Me A Trick" concept is a great example of how technology can help connect skaters around the world. Through this group people can challenge one another, give words of encouragement, help one another progress and also give a digital high-five. If you have a skateboard and the desire to learn something new, I highly recommend you join the community at Show Me A Trick.”

-Billy Meiners, Landyachtz Skateboards

story:
Short Summary

Veterans Get I.T. was developed to create opportunities for Veterans to establish a career in IT by building a foundation of expertise through classroom and hands on business experience. This program is unique in that it does not require previous skills in I.T., just the desire to learn and be part of this growing industry. It also offers veterans a livable salary while they are going through the program. :

  • My name is Michael St. John the VP of Sales and Marketing for Expetec of MI and serve as a Platoon Sergeant In the Michigan Army National Guard
  • This program is designed to help get veterans in the IT field with a full time job at Expetec Technology Services of Michigan with on the job training while they attend New Horizons Computer Learning Centers and get their certifications in IT. This is important to me because I as a Platoon sergeant see the struggle many Veterans go through trying to find a career but lack the experience because sometimes their military job does not transfer over. 
  • By contributing to our campaign you will help my organization employ 2 veterans in an IT company for two years while going through a management training program and getting their IT Certifications. Not only will this help the Veterans but it will bring more people in to the IT field, an industry that is struggling for talent in Metro Detroit. This program will give 2 veterans a chance at a new beginning.

What We Need & What You Get

The Funds will be used to pay the salary for 2 Veterans for 2 years and all the associated equipment and software they will need for the job. In addition it will cover the costs of the marketing items in the campaign. The funds will also cover the costs to educate and get the Veteran their IT certifications.  Lastly, the costs will go to cover the expense associated with recruiting and vetting the Veterans for the positions. If we do not reach our entire goal we will still put the money towards hiring Veterans. Based on your contributions you will see under the Perks page what you get in return for helping a Veteran. 

The Impact

The impact this has on our Veteran community is it gets them over the hump of not having experience when they leave the military needed to compete in today' s job market. By bringing Veterans in to the IT arena we are bringing in more disciplined talent that can perform under pressure. It also will help create more candidates to choose from and fill the many job openings that companies are struggling to fill due to lack of talent.


Risks & Challenges

Some of the challenges we may have is raising enough money to employ the Veterans for 2 years. To address this issue we have worked with the VA to take advantage of their Vocational Rehab program which will offset some of the costs for the first 6 months to pay the Veteran. In addition, we have worked with New Horizons who has secured Grants to fund the certifications the Veterans will need to succeed in the IT arena.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially but what you can do to help is share this program with your employer, friends and family to contribute. In addition, if you know a Veteran who may be interested have them apply for the opportunity.

Don't forget to share on Facebook, Twitter, Linkedin, Google +.

story:
Audio forums where people rave about my DACs


http://www.stereo.net.au/forums/index.php?/topic/71210-%E2%80%9Cthe-battery-dac-%E2%80%9C-impressions/
http://www.computeraudiophile.com/f6-dac-digital-analog-conversion/miniature-tda1543-brings-goods-10566/
http://www.audiocircle.com/index.php?topic=103678
http://theartofsound.net/forum/archive/index.php/t-26301.html
http://www.head-fi.org/t/709720/starting-point-systems-portable-nos-dac


Ebay evaluations I get about my DAC 2 (and the USB DAC 3 sounds better) ...



 


Why did you design this DAC ?
Nobody can be "told" what a good DAC is, you have to hear it for yourself...

After searching for the "perfect" DAC, I stumbled on forum discussions about how these "vintage" DACs from Phillips sounded so good.
I was getting a little skeptical about those "natural" and "analog" statements for the sound of those converters, but as so many people seemed to make converging descriptions, I was left with the feeling it was not just a legend...

I decided I had to build one, and try it for myself !

As the result was more than surprising... I told myself : wow, I got to show that to my friends...
And what most of my friends said : "can you build one for me ?"
Call that a market study...


Why do audiophiles do not like the sound of current oversampling DACs ?
Oversampling DACs are textbook correct, right ? So they should sound perfect, no ? Well ...

While it is true that oversampling DACs are textbook correct, if you make the wrong assumptions about the human hearing system, you may end up making mistakes, even if you do the math right !

Let me give you a simple example : it is generally assumed we hear the spectrum of sounds, but can't hear the phase.
Now try "binaural beats" on Google and listen for yourself. These clearly show the phase information IS sensed, AND remains present far inside the brain.

So maybe the spectrum-only approach to DAC design is not telling the whole story...

Traditional non-oversampling DACs from the past did not make any assumptions about hearing mechanisms, they just tried to replicate in analog what you fed them digitally as closely as possible...


What are the main features of this DAC ?
And what are the main goals of its design ?
  • Extract the pure performance of the last built non-oversampling true 16-bit TDA1543 DAC from Philips
  • Low jitter reclocker always active, on all inputs
  • Can run from either USB power alone (and recharge the batteries with it), or an external supply
  • Optical & Coaxial inputs (leftmost switch on the photo)
  • DIR9001 96 kHz SPDIF Receiver
  • Supports sampling frequencies from 28kHz to 108kHz (continous range, including non-standard frequencies)
  • TDA1543 16-bit DAC - the original from Philips®
  • Passive I/V conversion
  • No Op-Amp - direct output with 2Vpp (will drive any power amp well)
  • Huuuge capacitors on the output path provides sub-Hertz cutoff frequency (<0.3Hz on a 10kOhms input)
  • Dual Stage power supply regulation (for a super low background noise level)
  • Separate voltage regulators for the DAC and the Digital SPDIF receiver (same reason as above), also separated from microcontroller
  • Battery-powered with dual 9V NiMH batteries
  • Smart battery charger on-board (quickly charges the batteries when depleted, keeps them charged at low current when idle)
  • When both power switches are on, the batteries are recharged, and are also used to buffer the external power, completely removing hum.
  • Will Directly drive any power amplifier
  • Easy to carry around and make it listen to yours friends
  • 2+ hours of listening on the batteries alone


Why is the cost so low if it sounds so good ?
Simple is beautiful...

The less you process sound, by adding unnecessary stages, the more transparent result you get.
A minimalist non-oversampling DAC will achieve that goal, giving you great sound, and low cost too.

story:
The MAUIWatch Community Network is an all volunteer organization founded in July 2013.  Originally named after a prolific traffic officer, we started as a simple Facebook page that went from zero to thousands of fans in 72 hours. MAUIWatch’s popularity quickly dwarfed that of other news sites and government agencies specific to Maui County.

Today, MAUIWatch reaches over 100,000 people a month and have out grown our technical infrastructure. We started out with the typical cheap web hosting services you see all over the internet ranging from $5 to $15 a-month. We have outgrown this service by leaps and bounds and now require a dedicated web hosting solution. The cost to upgrade not only requires hardware and equipment but system administration staff to configure and administer the website.

Just 24 hours ago while breaking news of a shooting in Wailuku took place, the spike in web traffic was more than our servers could bear and the system crashed leaving many of you with system error messages. Thousands of residents rely on MAUIWatch and at this stage of growth, it will take a more significant financial obligation to stem the rising tide. 

We humbly ask for your support. If can, Can. If no can, No Can. Regardless. MAUIWatch will continue to provide you with the best breaking news coverage the best way we can.

story:
I was raised to believe we should all help each other.

We aren't designed to function alone in this world. We're meant to help each other out, stand up for each other, protect each other, and give of ourselves. I've spent my whole life giving my time and energy to those I love, sacrificing my own needs and desires to make other people happy. I want to give more. But I have very limited resources, and right now I am barely staying afloat. Ironically, with the best job I've ever had, I am now in an income bracket that disqualifies me from the free medical care I was getting under the AAC. Now that I have a decent job, I can't afford the chiropractic care, physical therapy, and psychotherapy that I need in order to just be able to function like a normal human being. I can't buy a house that doesn't have a leaky roof and holes in the floor like the 1975 trailer we're currently living in.  I can't help my kids, as they become adults and venture into the world. I can't help my youngest child, who has two life-threatening medical conditions and ongoing medical expenses. I can't help my community, or the women like me who have found themselves stuck in an abusive marriage and need help getting out. 
I want to help. But in order to be able to help people, first I need your help. 
Help me build a graphic design computer and buy a subscription to Adobe Cloud, so I can start my own business and get some extra income so I can help the people who need it. Help me put my education to use and bring some light to those around me. Help me make the world a better place.

I need a workstation and Adobe Cloud.

A good graphic design computer will cost me around $1300. This includes all the hardware and a monitor.
A high quality negative scanner will cost me around $700. This is important for doing any kind of photo restoration or work from negatives, as well as allowing me to scan actual photographs.
An annual subscription to Adobe Cloud will cost around $960. 
A 24" large format inkjet printer will cost me around $1300. This is not including paper and ink cartridges.
I figure $5,000 will get me started. One or two projects will keep me going.

I have lofty goals.

Of course, my main goal is to be able to provide a better life for myself and my family. I'm tired of living in poverty. I work full time and still don't have enough money to deal with the  normal situations life throws at me like home and auto repairs, illness, kids' field trips for school, etc. When buying school clothes and healthy food is a challenge to my budget, you can forget about luxuries like family vacations or even going to the movies.
But more than just giving my family a better life, I want to make the world a better place. I want to reach out into my community and give something back. I want to help women who are feeling scared, trapped, helpless. I want to lift up those who have fallen, and help them find their way into the light. My dream is to provide outreach and education for the general public, to help change society and how we deal with issues like domestic violence, poverty, and hatred. I want to help poor families get food, and have access to services. I want to do good things in the world. 
Starting my own business will give me the means to give *more* to my community. I will be able to really, truly, make the world a better place. Not just for my kids, but for everyone. Even if I don't reach my fundraising goal, the money will go toward starting that dream. And if I only raise $20, the money will go into my gas tank. (sorry, have to be honest)

I'm supposed to talk about risks & challenges.

There is always a risk of failure. There is a risk that life will happen, as it usually does. There is the risk that I'm not who I say I am, and that your money will go to fund a gun-smuggling operation out of Saskatoon. I can't promise you I will succeed in my attempt to start my own business. I can't promise you my business will be profitable. But I can promise you I won't smuggle any guns - and that I will work my ass off to make this dream a reality.  With your help, I can do it.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't comfortable donating cash, or if you don't have any to donate, that's OK. You can still help by sharing this link with your circle, in case any of your friends have spare cash lying around gathering dust. Hey, you might make their day, cleaning up a little extra space in their piggy banks! :)

story:
What is Oyooni? 

Oyooni is a non-profit organisation. All donations and funds raised go directly to the purchase of equipment. 

Oyooni aims to deliver effective treatment to the silent forgotten majority sufferers of diabetes in Palestine.

To reach, educate, screen, and manage every diabetic or potential diabetic in Palestine at no cost is Oyooni's mission.

Oyooni works with established diabetic care units in Palestine. Oyooni's added value is measured by providing an early detection facility to retinopathy (one of the complications of diabetes that can lead to blindness).

Oyooni has established a retinal screening program in partnership with the diabetic care unit at  Augusta Victoria Hospital in Jerusalem. Three members of their existing staff are trained to be graders (according to international standards). Images of the retina are sent electronically to Dr Ali Dabbagh for confirmed diagnosis. Patients with evidence of retinal complications are referred to laser treatment at a specialized eye care clinic/ hospital, if needed.

Periodic monitoring of all other patients progress is maintained through the diabetic care unit to prevent any potential complications from leading to blindness. 

What We Need & Why are we excited? 

We need to raise $20,000 to be able to purchase a camera for Oyooni's next base in Palestine. 

After the success, which is measured by the treatment and monitoring system explained above to over 2000 diabetic patients since 2011, we are excited to replicate the initiative in several other locations. 

Oyooni is currently eyeing out three further locations in Jenin, Gaza, and a Lebanon-based refugee camp. The final decision of selecting the next location is related to the readiness of the local clinics and staff.

The Impact

Direct impact on patients: an early detection process of any retinal complications  that may potentially cause blindness. 

Direct impact on health care staff: the training provided by Oyooni empowers  Palestinian health care staff and puts them in the driving seat. They can periodically monitor their patients retinal changes and act accordingly. Building a data bank of those images for record keeping is an added advantage. 

Risks & Challenges

Oyooni operates in an area under a military occupation. Logistical obstacles may cause delays as a result. We operate with utmost flexibility and may need to change the location of the next clinic as the situation dictates. 

This is why we always plan and prepare 3 possible locations to install our next camera.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please feel free to forward this pledge to other family members and friends who you think would be interested in supporting us.


Note: 

You will be contacted by a member of Indiegogo team to confirm your contribution. Unless you respond to them (within 7days), your contribution will be refunded to you.

story:
Provide sustainable living wages to 200 families in a developping country.

Our production provides good working condition and sustaintable living wages to more than 200 artisans and workers in Nepal. Recently affected by a major Earth quake, the country is now rebuilding and the work of its courageaous artisans is one of its most important source of income. Help us make a difference!

Support the development of Organic Cotton clothing. 

Our Cotton is a soft, bidodegradable and natural fiber. We chose to work only with Organic Cotton because conventionally-grown cotton uses 25% of the world's chemical pesticides (USDA, 2000). Less than 2% of the world’s cotton production is Organic. Choosing Organic Cotton helps protect soils, air, water and workers.


Anjuna (center) with Rakhi, Chandrakala, Pandey and Apsala, our  friends and coordination team in Nepal. 


WHO WE ARE 

Francis had 8 years experience with fair trade producers in Nepal and India. When he met Anjuna, a visual artist and project manager, they became lovers, and travelled together. In Nepal, they built a partnership with skilfull artisans  to produce eclectic fair trade clothing. The ADRIA Mode project was born. Back home, they developped a network of over 150 stores who distribute their clothing in Canada and the US. . 

"I design clothing for active women who like to create their own style and colors in accordance to their core values. My parents and family were artisans, we lived in an ecological house and had a big Organic garden. This project is very close to my hearth." - Anjuna, Designer 


FAIR TRADE CLOTHING 

Handcrafted details and handmade prints make our designs distinctive. They are made by talented handcrafters in the Himalayas.  "When I work with them, I feel like being back with my family. They are kind and authentic people." - Anjuna

We work and live with these people a few months per year. It was important for us to make sure they earn fair and sustainable living wages. The Fairtrade Federation logo on our clothing recognized our efforts to respect the women and men who produce our clothing. 

More info on : www.fairtradefederation.org/


CHOOSING ORGANIC

For us, taking care of our planet and our health is as important as wearing nice looking clothes we feel good in. This is why we chose to design with Organic fabrics. Our Organic Cotton is a soft, biodegradable and low-impact fabric. We use water-based handmade prints and recycle production cut-outs to make details. Our labels are also printed on hand-made sustainable fiber paper. Learn more about our certified Organic Cotton : www.global-standard.org/




TO THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT, YOU MAY CHOOSE TO RECEIVE: 


 15$ THANKS from all our hearth and  

GET our NEW Eco-Ethic Fashion E-MAGAZINE (english/français)



                                                                                          55$ THANKS from all our hearth and 
                  GET A  CIRCUS shirt (S-XXL)

 

85$ THANKS from all our hearth and 

GET A POPPY Dress (S-XXL)



100$ - THANKS from all our hearth and GET a CIRCLE Jacket (S-XXL) 


120$ - THANKS from all our hearth and GET a MANDU Jacket (S-XXL)



Want to know more about us?

https://www.facebook.com/ADRIAMode

http://www.adriamode.com/


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

-  Share the project on your Facebook

-  Send and email our campaign to your contacts

-  Use Indiegogo sharing tools

- Tweet your support to this campaign

-  Talk to your favorite store about us!


Give us feedback: info@adriamode.com

Thank you so much!!!

Anjuna & Francis

story:
Charming, top-rated bar operating 4 years with devoted customers from all continents -- caught suddenly in difficult situation!  My outside  consulting job is what I have been making advance rental payments with, after greedy landlord demanded accelerated rent payments.  But my European-government-employer is in a tangle with Asian-government-client, and that will be solved (or there will be an *ugly* diplomatic encounter!), but as employeeswe are suddenly not being paid and my bar will be shut because I can't quickly finish paying jacked-up rent in advance! (Was close, but...)  Landlord (1) accelerated our due dates, (2) when I stopped getting paid, *denied* any extension, and (3) decided we were unreliable because I stopped getting paid, so punished us by demanding full payment immediatetly, and (4) not according to the ambitious payment schedule she herself had proposed.  This abuse is after her getting paid steadily over 4 years!!

Quality: 4 and 1/2 stars leaning toward  5 on TripAdvisor, Certificate of Excellence 2015!  PLEASE help us stay in business; we basically do this for love, we sure don't make much money doing it!  Bar has over $100,000 in fancy renovations (best bathroom in Southern Thailand!), and that will be a 90% loss at least if we get closed permanently.  Please help!  We will recognize you with a nice perk (please see)! In next months, we start exports of specialty Thai foods to North America, and that is linked to this bar.  We will use the funds collected to pay 18 months' rent in advance, buy inventory (wine), and support a legal defense fund.  We do everthing with love and attention; we make the best cocktails in Hua Hin!  Le Bar Francais is a genuine part of Hua Hin, Thailandvlife now; let's make a strong campaign to save it!  You will save  the jobs of 5 *excellent* staff. This is a bar to bring a special person to, not a "girly bar" - *classy* instead!  Short campaign, need you and friends to contribute now!  PLEASE HELP!!  Thank you!!!  Come and see us too!  You will love it!

story:
8 West is a transitional employment + supportive housing program located in San Diego, California. We employ homeless youth to produce the highest-quality, ultra-premium handcrafted soap you've ever seen!

Our mission is deeply rooted in the belief that solutions to end homelessness must be sustainable to make a real difference. Accordingly, our "homeless to hopeful" model is based on an outreach strategy that seeks to embrace, cultivate and propel the homeless youth in our community. And we're making it happen RIGHT NOW ... are you ready to give a #handup?

Have you ever stopped to think how many homeless youth live on the streets in your community? Where do they sleep at night? How do they find food and medical care to nourish and heal their bodies? How do they get off the streets?

Here in San Diego, California, we have more than 3,000 homeless youth living and sleeping on our streets. Many arrive here from all over the United States. At 8 West, we've been working hard to forge relationships with these individuals in the homeless community since 2008. We understand the outlook of the homeless youth we work with every week. They feel abandoned. Forgotten. Discarded by the world. And for far too many, the chance to redeem themselves and re-join a community filled with hope seems like an unobtainable goal. Unfortunately, successfully transitioning off the streets is no small feat for these young people.

8 West was founded as a non-profit transitional employment + housing program that seeks to sustainably end youth homelessness. With the #handup approach in our "homeless to hopeful" model, we provide jobs (as many of them as we can), safe housing (for as many as we can) and social, health and educational support for homeless youth who are ready to change their lives for the better - forever.

Our Artisans produce the highest-quality handcrafted soap you will find on the market. The next time you find yourself around a conventional bar of soap (or a bottle of liquid soap), take a moment to read the ingredients. Snap a photo and post it to the 8 West page on Instagram or Facebook.

And try to read the ingredients aloud. The differences in quality and sustainability between these products and the 8 West premium bar soap are astounding. Other soap products are made almost entirely of harsh and semi-harsh chemicals and compounds that are produced in a laboratory. On the other hand, 8 West premium bar soap is made entirely of the highest grades of oils and butters, always all natural and always great for your skin.

We're raising $500,000 to expand the scale, scope and impact of our program. Every dollar committed to 8 West results in more jobs, more housing and more opportunity for homeless youth living on the streets. We will make a HUGE DIFFERENCE in ending youth homeless whether we exceed our capital goal, meet it, or fall short. We're all-in on making this happen ... but we need your help!

We have supercool perks and all donations are tax deductible (we're a 501(c)(3) nonprofit, but please consult with a tax professional regarding your individual tax deduction eligibility). We also have a world-class team of creative, marketing and PR talent providing pro bono advisory support. With their guidance, we expect 8 West operations to be fully-funded through working capital (requiring no further capital infusions) at the conclusion of this campaign.

Our goal is to successfully graduate over 100 homeless youth through our 18-month transitional program by 2020. The tangible impact of the program is seeing self-sufficient graduates go on to employment and housing opportunities that leverage their interests and skills. 8 West is a game changer and we welcome your involvement in helping those most in need.

Play a role today in helping to launch this sustainable #handup model that can have such a tremendous impact on so many homeless youth. And in addition to your support, please share our story with all your friends and family to help us meet our goal.

Buy 8 West soap today ... www.8west.org ... where Youth Homelessness Ends.

story:
Who We Are

Orange County DIY is non-profit organization that’s mission is to open the area’s first all ages, safer, sober, community driven arts and music space. Since 2014, the organization has thrown over 40 arts and music events put on for the youth of Orange County with the goal of creating an accessible, safe haven for artists of all backgrounds to express themselves.

 Orange County needs a center for artistic exploration and community engagement; a protected, safe haven for artists of all backgrounds to find respite where they are free to express without judgement or fear of expressing who they are. It is vital to have a space like this  because it provides the unique opportunity to build culture and community where there is none. 



 In order to adequately serve our vast artistic community it has been our goal since day 1 to open our own space. We have set two financial goals for ourselves which we deem will provide us with enough money for 2 months rent, utilities, liability insurance, and proper permits. Our first fundraising goal was to reach $5000 which we recently achieved on June 5th, 2015. Now, with this IndieGogo, we plan to raise an additional $5000, for a total of $10,000, to make this space a reality.

In 2015 we secured our Non-Profit 501(c)(3) status as a charitable organization for public purposes. Since we do not yet have our own space we have been throwing events all across Orange County hosted by local businesses that support our mission. We are now in the final stages of completing our ultimate fundraising goal to move into our permanent space on Indie Gogo.


What We Need & What You Get

  • We deem that $10,000 will provide us with enough money for 2 months rent, utilities, liability insurance, and proper permits. We need this cushion so we can get into our space comfortably to effectively launch our operations as soon as possible. 



  • We've prepared a ton of perks for our donors, starting with getting your name permanently displayed in our space. We want all of our contributors to be remembered in our space. Additionally, we will be releasing a limited edition t-shirts and hoodie, designed by our original logo designer, Wyatt Kollar. You can get the t-shirt by itself, but we recommend taking a look at some of our package options as well. In the packages we will be including releases from local artists and musicians, as well as a new, free show pass (The Multipass - Yes, from that movie) that we're launching just for the campaign. We have some cooler donation rewards higher up the tree so please take a look at those! 

The Impact

Creating a central hub for community driven arts and music events in Orange County is great, but not entirely game-changing. What we aim to provide is a space where not only can people come book their own shows and host their own events, but a place where we can continually stimulate our growing community by bringing in new artists and giving them a platform to start and build from. 


Growing up in Orange County we were used to the fact that if you wanted to see good, live music that’s accessible to everyone you would have to drive all the way to LA or San Diego. The only other opportunities this area has for its youth is playing inside bars or getting taken advantage of in “pay-to-play” scenarios. Having a good place to express and show art in front of peers within a trusted community is something we don't just need in this area, but something our young artists and entire community deserves. 


Risks & Challenges

  • Keeping a space like this requires a strong adherence to our regulations on being a safer, sober, drug free environment.
  • To ensure that we're always bringing in and supporting new artists we require constant outreach and ways for people from the community to program their own events
  • We are a space that runs on volunteers. Without a reliable staff for each event we would not be able to continue hosting events for the public. 
We are confident in our ability to tackle all of these problems by our extensive experience with show running in and outside of the organization. We now have a dedicated staff that works specifically with volunteers, a community manager that works with individuals looking to propose events, and a designated booker to keep tabs on new and upcoming artists looking for a place to play. 



Communicating our rules and regulations to our audience before entering the space is key to having an understanding with our guests. We list our rules and codes of conduct outside all of our events so that guests can be aware of our rules, why they exist, and their consequences if unmet, before entering our space. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have money to donate that's fine! A lot of us on the team currently have no money. We get it. But please, share our cause. You can visit us on our website or on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, or Instagram. 
OrangeCountyDIY.org
facebook.com/orangecountyDIY
instagram.com/orangecountydiy
If you know any musicians, artists, vendors, educators, etc., please share this with them! This will benefit everyone in our community so the more people that know, the better!

story:
What is FiM?

We are Freedom in Motion (FiM), a parkour training facility created by Temecula Valley's very own parkour athletes. 

It is our mission to inspire the next generation to go outside and play with their environment in creative new ways. We teach people of all ages to live healthy lifestyles and to passionately seek improvement in all aspects of life. 

We're being forced to move out, and find a new home. 

Our students have learned to skillfully navigate parkour obstacles, and now it is FiM's turn to rise above one of life's unforeseen obstacles. The owners of our building are trying to sell the place, so that means we need to pick up and look for a new home. Rather than see this as the end of the road for FiM, we see it as a bright new opportunity, but one we will need to approach together.
     FiM has already made a tremendous impact in our community, and we are committed to continuing this work. We have found some potential new locations in Murrieta, and now we just need to raise some funds to make sure we can survive the move. Your support will enable us to rebuild our largest structures and compensate our coaches for their time rebuilding, since the entire construction project will be done by our staff.

We've done it before and we can do it again.

THANK YOU to everyone who contributed to our campaign last time. You rallied together, supporting the opening of Temecula Valley's first and only parkour gym. Together, we can overcome this new obstacle in our path toward freedom.

When we built FiM from scratch in 2014 (see above) it took countless hours and weeks of uncompensated labor by our coaches and community members. We are eternally grateful for that support, and we will need all hands on deck once again to make this move a success. If you are interested in joining FiM-2's building team or if you can offer in-kind support such as building materials and supplies, please contact us to let us know you're on board. If you want to help us make this move as seamless as possible, please consider donating to our cause today. 

Your Support -- Your Rewards

In order to re-build our gym, FiM needs lots of supplies and support. In return, we are offering one-time membership deals, custom gear, and other perks in exchange for your generous support. The funds we raise will primarily go toward the following:

  • Rubber flooring
  • Springs
  • Foam pit foam
  • Metal railings
  • Wood (lots of wood) and screws (lots of screws)
  • Compensation for coaches and building staff 
  • Returning our current warehouse to its empty former self 

Impact

Why is our project valuable to the public and to the world? 

  • It's all about the messages and movement we are spreading in our community! FiM's core values are creative thinking, community, inspiring one another, continuous growth, and achieving personal freedom. We strive to instill these values in our students and we need your support to advance our mission.
  • Freedom in Motion has thus far made a huge impact in our community, but this move may make or break our future. Contributing now will enable us to continue sharing parkour with Temecula Valley and beyond! 


Spread the Word! #SaveFiM

We recognize that some of our supporters don't have the means to contribute financially, and that doesn't mean we love you any less! You can be part of the #SaveFiM team by sharing this message on social media to help spread the word.

Visit our Facebook page, give us a Like, or make our banner your cover photo! Tag other FiM supporters, or even people you think would like to try parkour in your post! We have a wide audience, but there are even more potential traceurs and traceuses out there who haven't yet found their freedom. Please use these hashtags to connect your posts to other supporters' posts:
 #FreeYourself
#FreedomInMotion
#SaveFiM

Limited edition Metallic shirts for those who contribute. 

California Parkour shirt for those who donate $30


Own a small business?
FiM has some custom perks for companies who would like to get involved. Contributing as a business will earn you a booth at our re-grand opening event, a banner hung in our gym, and more! If you own a business, or anyone you know does, please reach out to us and we'll send the business options and more information your way!

Come check out our current gym!
Every month of membership you use and every visit to our gym is a big help to us. Even just walking into the gym and moving around will help us reach our goals. If you haven't been in for some time, or you would like to say goodbye to our current location you don't have much time left -- we will be moved out by June 31st!

Thank you for taking the time to read all the way through our story. We hope we've inspired you to get out, move around, and make today's version of yourself the best version of you that's ever been! 

Lets get moving!
<3 The FiM Team

                            

FREE  YOURSELF

story:
日本語版

 




my Story

Hello my name is Yoko and I am an Ayurvedic therapist and yoga instructor. I am starting a small business called Ayuela Beauté in my hometown of Utsunomiya, Japan. The space will have a yoga studio, massage room and a retail area for natural beauty products, clothing and jewelry.  I am starting this campaign in order to raise funds for opening the business by March next year. 

 

My passion in life has always been beauty and my focus in Ayuela Beauté is to share the joy of living beautifully. 

 

Since my late teens I have always been involved in the hair and beauty industry and my passion for it took me to New York.  After many years working as a stylist I opened Ueno Salon on Mulberry street in 2002 and another branch soon after in the east village. Both were very successful and it was as if all my dreams came true but I still felt something missing. It was after an emergency room visit for an allergic reaction that I soon focused on health and lifestyle changes. I was introduced to Ayurveda, a 5,000 year old healing system from India. It promotes health and well-being through the balance of mind, body and spirit. I took courses and classes in esthetics and ayurveda but still wanted to experience more… 

 

I closed both salons and decided to leave New York to pursue this new direction…I dreamed of a place to share in reconnecting to our true inner beauty through health and happiness.  This took me first to Paris then India where I enrolled in an Ayurvedic Health care center and received certification as a therapist. I then moved to Hawaii to study massage therapy and took a teacher training course for Yoga. 

 

Returning to Japan I found that my search for a place to open Ayuela Beaute brought me back to family, to friends… it brought me back home. 

 

Ayuela Beaute is almost there but not without you. It is through you that this dream becomes reality and in return I offer my thanks and appreciation through our campaign perks. 

 

I am offering ayurvedic massage, yoga classes and am very excited to offer merchandise from LOUISE MANNA Jewelry and ANA, both of whom I will also be collaborating with for a future line of yoga inspired fashion wear and gear.

 

Once again I thank you for sharing this dream with me…


Live beautifully. 

 

Domo arigato.







 



the Perks!

特典



This is a flexible funding campaign which allows us to keep what we raise. This gives us an opportunity to make these perks available for Christmas delivery, dependent on destination and purchase date. PLEASE SPECIFY if this is a GIFT and would like delivery in time for CHRISTMAS, otherwise all products and gift cards will be shipped in March of 2016. If you have any concerns or questions, please email us prior to ordering.  


Multiple Perks can be purchased as gifts for the holidays.


* you can find full size photos & videos in the gallery section(top of page).



GIFT CARDS

In time for the holiday seasons we are offering exclusive deals in the form of Gift Cards for Yoga Memberships & Classes and Ayurvedic oil massage treatments for those able to join us at Ayuela Beauté in Utsunomiya, Japan. 



ana

Specializing in African fabrics, ana offers Clutches, Travel and Make Up Pouches and Bandanas in a wide assortment of styles and designs. All items will be shipped worldwide from Japan in March 2016 unless requested for holiday delivery. 

JAPAN DOMESTIC SHIPPING(for Holiday Delivery): Orders received up to December 16th for delivery within Japan should give suitable time to receive items before Christmas. Expedited shipping can also be made available.

USA & WORLD SHIPPING(for Holiday Delivery): All other orders to USA and abroad should consider December 12th as an order deadline to insure adequate shipping time via JapanPost Airmail (approximately 5-8 days to USA & Europe delivery time).Please contact us about expedited shipping options. Japan's EMS(Express Mail Service) offers 3 day service for approximately ¥1200 (or appr. $10) for most items listed.



Louise Manna Jewelry

An extensive range of exclusive rings, bracelets, necklaces and earrings from Louise Manna Jewelry.  All items will be shipped worldwide from the US in March 2016 unless requested for holiday delivery. 

USA DOMESTIC SHIPPING(for Holiday Delivery): Orders will be shipped from New York.  Orders received up to December 12th for US destinations should give suitable time to receive items before Christmas via priority mail. 

JAPAN & WORLD(for Holiday Delivery): Allow at least two weeks for First Class International mail order delivery. We recommend placing your order by December 6th at the very latest but due to the holiday traffic we cannot guarantee orders to be delivered by the 24th. Please contact us about expedited shipping options for holiday deliveries.  

 






For more details concerning terms and gift card redemption please visit our website at ayuelabeaute.com

story_txt:
日本語版






 















my Story
Hello my name is Yoko and I am an
Ayurvedic therapist and yoga instructor. I am starting a small business called
Ayuela Beauté in my hometown of Utsunomiya, Japan. The space will have a
yoga studio, massage room and a retail area for natural beauty products,
clothing and jewelry.  I am starting this campaign in order to raise funds
for opening the business by March next year. 
 
My passion in life has always been beauty
and my focus in Ayuela Beauté is to share the joy of living beautifully. 
 
Since my late teens I have always been
involved in the hair and beauty industry and my passion for it took me to New
York.  After many years working as a stylist I opened Ueno Salon on
Mulberry street in 2002 and another branch soon after in the east village. Both
were very successful and it was as if all my dreams came true but I still felt
something missing. It was after an emergency room visit for an allergic
reaction that I soon focused on health and lifestyle changes. I was introduced
to Ayurveda, a 5,000 year old healing system from India. It promotes health and
well-being through the balance of mind, body and spirit. I took courses and
classes in esthetics and ayurveda but still wanted to experience more… 
 
I closed both salons and decided to leave
New York to pursue this new direction…I dreamed of a place to share in reconnecting
to our true inner beauty through health and happiness.  This took me first
to Paris then India where I enrolled in an Ayurvedic Health care center and
received certification as a therapist. I then moved to Hawaii to study massage
therapy and took a teacher training course for Yoga. 
 
Returning to Japan I found that my search
for a place to open Ayuela Beaute brought me back to family, to friends… it
brought me back home. 
 
Ayuela Beaute is almost there but not
without you. It is through you that this dream becomes reality and in return I
offer my thanks and appreciation through our campaign perks. 
 
I am offering ayurvedic massage, yoga
classes and am very excited to offer merchandise from LOUISE MANNA Jewelry and
ANA, both of whom I will also be collaborating with for a future line of yoga
inspired fashion wear and gear.
 
Once again I thank you for sharing this
dream with me…

Live beautifully. 
 
Domo arigato.

















 





the Perks!

story:
Honoring the History and the Journey

We began our journey together behind a humble lunch counter tucked inside a beloved, long-standing health food store where community, good food, and social responsibility are the core values. With the recently announced closure of Healthy Foods Market, we are dedicated to carrying those values into the future.


  • I grow my roots deep. I changed my name the summer before sixth grade to become the fourth Amenie in my family because I value that kind of living heritage. I chose to settle in the town I grew up in, having lived elsewhere only to find that my home (and heart) has always been here, nestled between the mountains and history of Lexington, VA. My husband, Damon, and I met, worked, and fell in love together behind this lunch counter at the center of Lexington's venerable Healthy Foods Market. This campaign is all about acknowledging our personal journeys and honoring the rich history of local food and social activism that has shaped our exquisite hometown. The Blue Phoenix Cafe & Market is a nod to the Blue Heron Cafe, which is where I worked my first restaurant job and consequently discovered the creative, connective power of food. It also pays homage to the recent  loss in our community of Healthy Foods Market which in 43 years of business was never just a store, but a beautifully inclusive space where people gathered as strangers and left as friends. It is from the proverbial ashes of Healthy Foods that our new cafe and market will take shape.
  •                             
  • In many ways I think of our work as social art, with food as our medium. Each plate is a canvas, inviting people to gather, experiencing something new together, and go back out into the world subtly nourished in body and spirit. Building on our individual journeys and community legacies, The Blue Phoenix Cafe and Market will hold an open place in our downtown for people to gather and reconnect with one another, to feel safe, welcomed, and accepted.
  • Your contributions today provide more than just capital for expanding an established business. When you give, you are directly involved with community building through a social-entrepreneurial project where each decision is governed by a core imperative to provide social, physical, mental, and emotional nourishment to everyone who walks through our door. 
  • Every. One. Every. Day. No one goes away empty.

What We Need 

$65,000 to build a sustainable, food-based community center. Since we're bringing with us almost four years of steadily increasing sales, marketing, menu development, and customer loyalty, most of your contributions will go directly to expansion of services and rejuvenation. Below is the  break-out of what your generosity and direct involvement will create. We decided to aim high, laying out the whole shebang, and giving you all the details of what it's going to take to reach our ultimate destination. We don't need the entire fundraising goal to keep the doors open but every extra dollar that you give is a critical piece in constructing a strong business capable of consistently giving back to the community that built it. 

  • Overhead Costs during the transition to The Blue Phoenix and for the first three months of operation $6,000: rent, utilities, licensing, insurance, etc.
  • Equipment & Structural Improvements $5,000: we're trying to purchase and re-purpose as much equipment, shelving, counters, and physical assets from Healthy Foods as possible. It helps them close financially solvent and it helps us keep expansion costs low. There are a few items, like a new display cooler for our meal kits, that we'll have to purchase outright.
  • Labor $5,000: we're planning on putting a lot of sweat equity into our new business, but there are some projects that require expert help and we're going to need cash on hand to pay our talented area craftsmen and helpers.
  • Inventory and Ingredients $12,000: it's time to fill the shelves (and the kitchen), preferably with as much locally sourced products and produce as we can find. Here is where we get to take your dollars and invest them right back into the community. 
  • Point of Sale System $3,000: this will help us keep track of sales and inventory more accurately, speed up the checkout process, and provide better customer service and kitchen efficiency.
  • Payroll $12,000: it takes a significant investment to recruit and train an awesome staff and it's very, VERY important to us that our business model is strong enough to achieve and sustain a living wage for every single employee. 
  • Advertising $2,000: although we'll be doing some paid social media advertising, most of our advertising budget will go to ads and sponsorships placed with athletic or academic groups, non-profits, and other similar organizations in our area. We want our marketing to count for more than just getting the word out and keeping our money local helps achieve that goal.
  • Total Kitchen Renovation $20,000: this is the biggie, so we've saved it for last. Our cafe kitchen is charmingly shabby with its DIY, patched together, punk appeal, but it's literally coming apart at the seams. Here's the short list of what needs to happen: expand the total space, install a commercial hood with fire suppression system, remove and replace the floor, install a backsplash, purchase and install new worktops, sandwich prep unit, stove and grill, paint, and raise the dish sink.


What You Get

  • Handcrafted, creative food from the area's ONLY exclusively vegetarian & vegan eatery serving breakfast, lunch, and (eventually) dinner!
  • The development of a warm, accessible, public venue for music, art, learning, and socializing.
  • Lexington's only downtown grocery store and year-round, indoor farmers market
  • Meal kits for those who want healthy, home-cooked food but don't always have time to find recipes and prep all the ingredients.
  • A Buyer's Club where you can special order organic and natural foods and products at a huge discount. 
  • An "Everyone Eats" policy that ensures there will always be at least one menu item that is priced on a pay-what-you-can model so that everyone who wants to may enjoy a dignified, lovingly prepared meal. 
  • Partnerships and collaborations with other area organizations, especially those that provide education, health, outreach, and relief services.
  • Connection and Community. We can't say it enough!! This really is the bottomline, the reason for everything we do.

  • If we do not reach our total funding goal, we will implement a more moderately phased business plan. Our goals and values will remain constant, it's just going to take more time to affect the same degree of community enrichment and impact.

Speaking of Impact...

The Lexington of my childhood was a very different place. Main Street was home to three groceries, a hardware store, a pharmacy, and even a small department store. It was a thriving market place built for and sustained by the local populace. I want to see those stores return. I want to help build a local economy that supplies basic, daily needs in addition to the draw of beautiful boutiques and elegant restaurants. 

Keeping the doors open to the last downtown grocery is a deliberate, socioeconomic investment and radical display of local activism. Our continued operation, our growth and viability, is a vital step in building a resilient downtown and network of personally invested, connected individuals. The resurgence of needs-based Main Street businesses encourages people to put down the screen, leave their car at home, keep money local, and deepen ties with other residents. 

I'm a child of the technology era. I've never known a time without computers. I have a smartphone, tablet, and laptop. I'm hyper-connected just like most of you and I love all my technological tools. I'm using them to achieve a crowdfunding goal right now. But if all that technology went away tomorrow, what would we have left? 

I want that answer to include a community where I can walk down the street to pick up groceries, household supplies, a prescription, lunch with a colleague, coffee with a friend, and know that if I'm running late my neighbor two houses down can watch my child until I get home. 

I want to live in a world nurtured with trust, authenticity, and equity. Four years ago I left a stable, secure, but demoralizing job to go work at a tiny health food store where the pay was terrible, the work challenging, and the future tenuous. I've never looked back with regret. I gained a sense of belonging so deep and a community so committed that it is with tremendous hope and dedication I am ready to make the next leap of faith.

But Look Before You Leap (This goes for you, too)

It is an understatement to say that the Lexington community and store membership were shocked when the Board of Directors announced the closing of Healthy Foods Market. It has shaken our collective confidence in the ability of the small, independent grocery and cafe to make it in a world filled with big box stores, food franchises, and convenient, less expensive online retailers. There are undeniable logistical hurdles to be cleared. Raising support, awareness, and capital top the action list. 

I do not expect anyone to blindly leap across the void without first checking that there is at least some possibility of success. I have spent the last year looking both behind and ahead. The Blue Phoenix Cafe and Market represents the meticulous harvest of the richest elements of Lexington's whole foods movement. We've carefully nurtured the vision with plenty of lessons learned from our mistakes (and successes) and now we're ready to let it grow into something beautiful, resilient, and fulfilling. We're not going to do everything at once. No one is going to do this alone. We are lovingly, trustingly reaching out to clasp your hand. It's going to take a village.


Other Ways to Help:

Not everyone gives in the same way so here are some suggestions for other ways to pitch in:

  • Network! Share! Inspire! Spread word of our campaign with friends, neighbors, and families. Social media is an especially powerful tool for connection and activism, but picking up the phone is marvelous too.
  • If you're in town, come visit the store! The doors will be open under Healthy Foods Market & Cafe through January. See for yourself why we are all so passionate about this little corner of Lexington.
  • If you're local, we're going to need all the help we can get during our transition to The Blue Phoenix. Skills, services, advice, elbow grease, raw materials, equipment, and tools are all appreciated. Nothing says "together" like a barn (or store) raising.
  • Surprise us! There are probably millions of ways to help that we haven't even thought of, so let us know!

It helps them close financially solvent and it helps us keep expansion costs low. There are a few items, like a new display cooler for our meal kits, that we'll have to purchase outright.
Labor $5,000: we're planning on putting a lot of sweat equity into our new business, but there are some projects that require expert help and we're going to need cash on hand to pay our talented area craftsmen and helpers.
Inventory and Ingredients $12,000: it's time to fill the shelves (and the kitchen), preferably with as much locally sourced products and produce as we can find. Here is where we get to take your dollars and invest them right back into the community. 
Point of Sale System $3,000: this will help us keep track of sales and inventory more accurately, speed up the checkout process, and provide better customer service and kitchen efficiency.
Payroll $12,000: it takes a significant investment to recruit and train an awesome staff and it's very, VERY important to us that our business model is strong enough to achieve and sustain a living wage for every single employee. 
Advertising $2,000: although we'll be doing some paid social media advertising, most of our advertising budget will go to ads and sponsorships placed with athletic or academic groups, non-profits, and other similar organizations in our area. We want our marketing to count for more than just getting the word out and keeping our money local helps achieve that goal.
Total Kitchen Renovation $20,000: this is the biggie, so we've saved it for last. Our cafe kitchen is charmingly shabby with its DIY, patched together, punk appeal, but it's literally coming apart at the seams. Here's the short list of what needs to happen: expand the total space, install a commercial hood with fire suppression system, remove and replace the floor, install a backsplash, purchase and install new worktops, sandwich prep unit, stove and grill, paint, and raise the dish sink.





What You Get
 Handcrafted, creative food from the area's ONLY exclusively vegetarian & vegan eatery serving breakfast, lunch, and (eventually) dinner!
The development of a warm, accessible, public venue for music, art, learning, and socializing.
Lexington's only downtown grocery store and year-round, indoor farmers market
Meal kits for those who want healthy, home-cooked food but don't always have time to find recipes and prep all the ingredients.
A Buyer's Club where you can special order organic and natural foods and products at a huge discount. 
An "Everyone Eats" policy that ensures there will always be at least one menu item that is priced on a pay-what-you-can model so that everyone who wants to may enjoy a dignified, lovingly prepared meal. 
Partnerships and collaborations with other area organizations, especially those that provide education, health, outreach, and relief services.
Connection and Community. We can't say it enough!! This really is the bottomline, the reason for everything we do.



If we do not reach our total funding goal, we will implement a more moderately phased business plan. Our goals and values will remain constant, it's just going to take more time to affect the same degree of community enrichment and impact.    Speaking of Impact... The Lexington of my childhood was a very different place. Main Street was home to three groceries, a hardware store, a pharmacy, and even a small department store. It was a thriving market place built for and sustained by the local populace. I want to see those stores return. I want to help build a local economy that supplies basic, daily needs in addition to the draw of beautiful boutiques and elegant restaurants. 
Keeping the doors open to the last downtown grocery is a deliberate, socioeconomic investment and radical display of local activism. Our continued operation, our growth and viability, is a vital step in building a resilient downtown and network of personally invested, connected individuals. The resurgence of needs-based Main Street businesses encourages people to put down the screen, leave their car at home, keep money local, and deepen ties with other residents. 
I'm a child of the technology era. I've never known a time without computers. I have a smartphone, tablet, and laptop. I'm hyper-connected just like most of you and I love all my technological tools. I'm using them to achieve a crowdfunding goal right now. But if all that technology went away tomorrow, what would we have left? 
I want that answer to include a community where I can walk down the street to pick up groceries, household supplies, a prescription, lunch with a colleague, coffee with a friend, and know that if I'm running late my neighbor two houses down can watch my child until I get home. 
I want to live in a world nurtured with trust, authenticity, and equity. Four years ago I left a stable, secure, but demoralizing job to go work at a tiny health food store where the pay was terrible, the work challenging, and the future tenuous. I've never looked back with regret. I gained a sense of belonging so deep and a community so committed that it is with tremendous hope and dedication I am ready to make the next leap of faith.
But Look Before You Leap (This goes for you, too)   It is an understatement to say that the Lexington community and store membership were shocked when the Board of Directors announced the closing of Healthy Foods Market. It has shaken our collective confidence in the ability of the small, independent grocery and cafe to make it in a world filled with big box stores, food franchises, and convenient, less expensive online retailers. There are undeniable logistical hurdles to be cleared. Raising support, awareness, and capital top the action list. 
I do not expect anyone to blindly leap across the void without first checking that there is at least some possibility of success. I have spent the last year looking both behind and ahead. The Blue Phoenix Cafe and Market represents the meticulous harvest of the richest elements of Lexington's whole foods movement. We've carefully nurtured the vision with plenty of lessons learned from our mistakes (and successes) and now we're ready to let it grow into something beautiful, resilient, and fulfilling. We're not going to do everything at once. No one is going to do this alone. We are lovingly, trustingly reaching out to clasp your hand. It's going to take a village.




    Other Ways to Help: Not everyone gives in the same way so here are some suggestions for other ways to pitch in:  Network! Share! Inspire! Spread word of our campaign with friends, neighbors, and families. Social media is an especially powerful tool for connection and activism, but picking up the phone is marvelous too. If you're in town, come visit the store! The doors will be open under Healthy Foods Market & Cafe through January. See for yourself why we are all so passionate about this little corner of Lexington.
If you're local, we're going to need all the help we can get during our transition to The Blue Phoenix. Skills, services, advice, elbow grease, raw materials, equipment, and tools are all appreciated. Nothing says "together" like a barn (or store) raising.
Surprise us! There are probably millions of ways to help that we haven't even thought of, so let us know!

story:
Aviva Romm is a Yale trained medical doctor, midwife and herbalist. I am passionate and committed to attend this course to learn more about herbal medicine and the benefits it can bring to women of all walks of life. 

This course will expand my knowledge and understanding of the earth and how its natural rhythms effect our everyday health.   

I will take this knowledge and apply it to my work as a doula, as a supplier of organic all-natural health products and as a pregnant mother of three preschoolers. 

Despite my busy, child-filled life I am excited by becoming more able to better serve the women and families in our community. Thank you, and every bit helps!!

Jasmine McAllister
